Title.evidence: This randomized controlled trial aimed to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of liposomal bupivacaine versus bupivacaine hydrochloride in patients receiving QLB-LSAL after laparoscopic nephrectomy.

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to two groups in a 1:1 ratio.

Participants.evidence: A total of 116 patients were scheduled to undergo elective laparoscopic nephrectomy under general anesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: The liposomal bupivacaine group (n = 53) received a mixture of 10 mL of liposomal bupivacaine (133mg) and 10 mL of normal saline, totaling 20 mL, while the bupivacaine hydrochloride group (n = 53) received 20 mL of 0.375% bupivacaine hydrochloride.

Objective.evidence: This randomized controlled trial aimed to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of liposomal bupivacaine versus bupivacaine hydrochloride in patients receiving QLB-LSAL after laparoscopic nephrectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was total morphine equivalent consumption within the first 48 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to two groups in a 1:1 ratio.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 116 patients were scheduled to undergo elective laparoscopic nephrectomy under general anesthesia.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The liposomal bupivacaine group (n = 53) received a mixture of 10 mL of liposomal bupivacaine (133mg) and 10 mL of normal saline, totaling 20 mL, while the bupivacaine hydrochloride group (n = 53) received 20 mL of 0.375% bupivacaine hydrochloride.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The total consumption of morphine equivalents within 48 hours postoperatively was significantly lower in the liposomal bupivacaine group than in the bupivacaine hydrochloride group (mean ± SD: 31.8 ± 2.3 vs 20.7 ± 2.8, 95% Confidence Intervals: 10.1 to 12.1, P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: no significant difference in the incidence of adverse events (P > 0.05) was observed between the two groups.
